messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> There are some dialects in which different words are
> pronounced exactly the same, and one can only tell what the word means
> by context. I had an Irish friend many years back who pronounced "my" as
> "me." In my own case, I pronounce "women" as "womun." The singular and
> the plural have no difference for me. But I would never think of writing
> both words identical, certainly not in TO, but really not in QS, either.

Differences in particular words are one thing; broad systematic
differences in patterns of sound are quite another. (It's not clear
whether "me" for "my" is a special pronunciation of the word "my",
or a special use of the word "me", BTW.)

> In the same vein, I think dialects such as
> the one you describe would naturally write in a standard dialect. I
> think you are bringing up a rare case, one in which some speakers
> distinguish between two words with sounds that others would not be able
> to hear.

Well, let's take an example I *can* document: in Australian English,
"come" and "calm" are a minimal pair differing only in vowel length.
Nor is the distinction confined to this one word: *all* the words that
use IPA [V] in N.A. and the U.K. use [a] in Australia, and all the ones
with IPA [A] are pronounced using [a:]. QS, alas, has no letter for IPA
[a] at all, much less [a:], only for IPA [A] and IPA [V] (#32 Ah and
#36 Utter, respectively).

Are you going to argue that twenty million people should write in some
dialect they only hear on TV? Or does QS need another letter? Or do
we allow people to use the QS letters to represent the oppositions that
are in fact natural for their way of speaking English?

(Note that English doesn't really have any standard dialects: cultivated
people in Boston, Dallas, Atlanta, San Francisco, London, Sydney,
Pretoria, and New Delhi don't even aspire to speak the same way, never
mind actually doing so. Indeed, in the U.S. the differences between
varieties are growing wider, not narrower, and two new widely spoken
dialects have appeared that did not exist sixty years ago.)

> My understanding is that QS does have enough phonemes to describe
> everyone's dialect. If there are lots of cases in which speakers use the
> same sound, but in different ways to mean a different word, that means
> that there are more than 40 phonemes, and that QS is inadequate in how
> it was devised and how we think of it.

Only if you hold on to the assumption that phonemes = sounds, which they
aren't. I don't blame you for being confused on this point; Read plainly
was also. It's also true that 40 phonemes is too few for some dialects
and too many for others, but as Michael Everson says, it's good enough.

> Anyway, you are saying that the sit-seat people should use different QS
> letters to distinguish between their words, but aren't you just
> describing a variation of TO? If you say that the words are different
> and that we are going to assign them letters not necessarily on how they
> sound, but just to distinguish them, then we are moving away from the
> phonomical basis for QS and towards the rigid spelling of TO.

Well, yes -- in the sense that TO was a phonemic (not phonetic)
orthography for the variety of English spoken in Southern England
about 500 years ago. It continues to make distinctions that only a
tiny minority of anglophones still make, and it utterly fails to make
distinctions that are necessary for the Englishes of today, either
because of the inadequacy of the un-extended Latin alphabet, or because
they were not yet made in that time, or simply because nobody noticed
them at the time when English spelling was first being standardized.
It's also full of absolutely pointless irregularities like the "h" in
"ghost", which serve no purpose whatsoever.

> But I don't think you can really base QS on phonemic opposition. It is
> more complicated than what I am suggesting. Of course, I understand that
> one can use phonemical opposition without understanding the principal
> behind it, but I don't see it as really a good way to describe how QS
> works. Aren't you just talking about the difference between phonemes and
> allophones?

Not entirely. In a single dialect, there may be multiple allophones
of a phoneme; but across dialects, *entirely different* sounds may be
used to represent common phonemes. Let's look at an example from the
consonants this time.

In the speech of many (not all) speakers of Irish English, the unvoiced
sound of "th" is represented not by a fricative, as elsewhere in the
world, but but by a stop. However, that does not mean that the t/th
opposition is lost and "tin" sounds exactly like "thin"; it does not.

Rather, "th" is pronounced using a dental stop, in which the tip of
the tongue touches the back of the teeth (the same sound as in French,
Spanish, or Italian "t"), whereas "t" is pronounced as the rest of us do,
as an alveolar stop, where the tip of the tongue touches the ridges just
above the teeth. The two sounds are similar or indistinguishable to
most anglophones, but in Ireland they constitute a phonemic opposition --
they matter, they make a difference to understanding which word is
being spoken. (The same is true for the voiced sound of "th" vs. "d".)

What are the four million Irish to do? They seem to have the same
choices as the Australians with their low vowels:

(a) introduce two new QS letters for sounds unique to their dialect,
which nobody else will be able to read at all;

(b) learn a foreign dialect in order to become literate;

(c) write thin and tin, thy and die, thick and tick, breathe and breed,
and hundreds of other pairs of words exactly the same way while
continuing to distinguish them in speech (so much for the phonetic
principle!);

(d) go ahead and use #7 Thaw for their unvoiced dental stop and
#8 They for their voiced one.

I argue that (d) is the only sane choice.

> I think Read did more or less envision that QS covered all the
> phonemes in the English speaking world. He was wrong in thinking that
> the upper class British English would serve as a model for other
> dialects, and I think his limitation is causing confusion now.

Just so. QS does cover all the *phonemes* in most of the English-speaking
world, but it doesn't come close to covering all the *sounds*, as in the
examples I have given above and many more. What's more, representing
sounds rather than phonemes may frequently cause severe misreadings.
If you read Et-Key-See-It-No-Tea, do you quickly and automatically realize
that you are "hearing" someone from New Zealand, and read the spoken word
"accent" that you probably spell At-Key-See-Et-No-Tea?

Worse yet, if you see Namedot-Eat-Utter-No, do you perceive this as
"Ian", or do you correctly realize that someone from the general area of
Buffalo-Chicago-Indianapolis wrote this text, and the TO for that name
is "Ann"? (Some kids named "Ian" who move to that region do get laughed
at for having a girl's name, really.)

the shoulders of giants.
